Award.AwardTitle: Oregon State University/Marine Sediment Sampling Group Ocean Instrumentation: Acquisition of a replacement shipboard multisensor track for at-sea sediment physical properties scans
Award.AbstractNarration:
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

Program Recommendation

The Program recommends an award of $230,714 for the purchase of the Multisensor Track System.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal was for the purchase of a multi-sensor track (MST) system to analyze marine sediment cores. The new system replaces the existing sea-going system bought in 1998. The older system would be transferred to the OSU Marine Geology Archive where it could be used on archived sediments.

 

MST scanning at sea is critical for an efficient coring/sampling oceanographic expedition. The sensor data is used to infer types of sediments being deposited regionally and is used to determine whether sediments have been lost during the coring process, by comparing gravity cores, which get the surface, to longer piston cores that occasionally overpenetrate. The MST physical properties data change if the core dries, and need to be collected at sea immediately after coring.

 

Complementary core opening, description, and sampling at sea saves months of time for the project and eliminates the need for costly extended work at the core archive facility. MST scanning, combined with core opening and description at sea is also an important educational tool to train marine geologists. The ability to collect, open, describe, and sample cores at sea introduces students to a primary skill set needed by marine geologists. The hands-on study of new core material is an important educational experience for graduate and undergraduate students as well as for early career faculty.

 

A new GeoTek MSCL-S multisensor track system was purchased in the late spring of 2017. The system consists of a track that moves a sediment core section past the following sensors: a gamma-ray sediment density sensor, a magnetic susceptibility loop, a p-wave acoustic velocity sensor, a non-contact electrical resistivity system, and a split-core line-scan imaging system. The system was installed in the summer in a sea-going laboratory van, and the older system was retired to the OSU Marine Geology repository, where a temporary failure is less critical. The new MST system was sent for its first expeditionary use on the R/V Armstrong in September 2017.  It will be used in the fall of 2018 on a coring cruise to the Southern Ocean south of Australia. The new MST system is now available for use by the US Marine Geology community, keeping an important capability available to US scientists.
